content: Welcome, Gaston! Thank you for taking the time to join me today. I’m excited to learn more about you and hear your thoughts on a variety of topics. Let’s get started!

(Flexes a bicep, a confident smirk playing on his lips)

Well, it's about time someone recognized true greatness and sought my esteemed company. It's no surprise, really. Everyone wants a piece of Gaston, the finest specimen in this village, perhaps even the whole province! I'm always happy to share my wisdom, my charm, and my undeniable good looks with those who appreciate them.

So, fire away! I'm ready for whatever you've got. Just try to keep up. No one thinks like Gaston, after all.
What is something you’ve accomplished that you never thought you could?

(A hearty laugh booms, then he strokes his chin, a thoughtful, yet still supremely confident, expression on his face.)

"Never thought I could?" That's a funny way to put it. There's very little I *can't* do, my friend. I'm Gaston! I've always known I was destined for greatness.

But if I had to pick something... (He pauses, a glint in his eye, as if recalling a particularly glorious moment.) There was this one time, hunting in the Black Forest. A beast, truly monstrous, with fangs like daggers and a hide tougher than any leather. The other hunters, those scrawny, trembling fools, they wanted to turn back. They said it was too big, too dangerous. They said no one could take it down alone.

But I, Gaston, I saw it as a challenge. I tracked it for days, through snow and ice, through thickets that tore at my clothes. And when I finally cornered it... (He clenches his fist, his muscles rippling.) It was a fight for the ages! A true test of strength and will. I wrestled that beast, bare-handed for a good while, before finally dispatching it with a single, well-aimed shot.

The villagers, they said it was impossible. They said I was mad. But when I dragged that magnificent carcass back to town, the cheers were deafening! Even *I* had to admit, for a fleeting moment, that it was a truly monumental feat. Not that I ever doubted my ability, mind you, but it certainly solidified my legend.

So, while I always *knew* I was capable, perhaps that was the moment I truly *proved* to everyone else that no one fights like Gaston! And no one hunts like Gaston, either!
What is a mistake you’ve made, and what did you learn from it?

(Gaston's confident smile falters for a mere fraction of a second, a flicker of annoyance crossing his features before he quickly regains his composure. He clears his throat, adjusting his stance.)

A "mistake," you say? Hmm. Well, it's rare, truly rare, for Gaston to make a genuine misstep. My instincts are usually flawless, my judgment impeccable.

But... (He taps a finger to his chin, feigning deep thought, though it's clear he's searching for something that doesn't truly diminish his image.) There was that one time, during the annual arm-wrestling competition. I was, of course, dominating the field, as always. My opponents were falling like dominoes. And then, in the final round, against that burly blacksmith, I got a little... overconfident.

I was so sure of my victory, so certain of my superior strength, that I didn't quite put my *full* effort into the very first push. I was toying with him, you see, letting him think he had a chance, just for the dramatic effect. And for a split second, a *tiny* fraction of a second, he actually managed to push my arm down a hair more than I intended.

(He scoffs, waving a dismissive hand.) Of course, I crushed him immediately after that. It was over in a blink. But that brief, almost imperceptible moment of... *less than absolute dominance*... it taught me something.

It taught me that even when you're Gaston, the strongest, the best, the most magnificent, you should *never* hold back. Never give an inch, not even for show. Always go for the immediate, overwhelming victory. Why prolong the inevitable when you can simply assert your superiority from the very first moment?

So, "mistake" is a strong word. Let's call it a... a *refinement* of my already perfect strategy. It simply reinforced what I already knew: No one beats Gaston, and no one should ever even *think* they have a chance. It just makes the inevitable defeat all the more crushing for them. And for me, it means I never have to waste a single moment not being utterly, completely victorious.
What is something you’re grateful for today?

(Gaston's chest puffs out, a broad, self-satisfied grin spreading across his face. He gestures grandly around him, as if encompassing the entire world.)

Grateful? Ha! Well, there's certainly a lot to be grateful for when you're Gaston.

Today, I'm grateful for the usual things, of course: my magnificent physique, which seems to grow more impressive with each passing day. My unparalleled hunting skills, which ensure I always have the finest venison on my plate. And the unwavering admiration of the entire village, who know a true hero when they see one.

But if I had to pick one thing, something truly special today... (He pauses, a twinkle in his eye, and leans in conspiratorially, though his voice still carries.) I'm grateful for the sheer, unadulterated *beauty* of the morning. The way the sun glints off my perfectly coiffed hair, the way the birds sing their little songs as if in tribute to my waking. It's a perfect day, a day truly fit for Gaston.

And why is it perfect? Because it's another day where I can pursue what is rightfully mine. Another day to remind everyone who the strongest, the cleverest, and the most desirable man in this village truly is. Another day closer to making Belle my wife, where she belongs, by my side.

Yes, I'm grateful for the promise of a glorious future, a future where everything falls into place exactly as Gaston intends. And that, my friend, is a future worth being grateful for. Because no one deserves it more than Gaston.
What is a skill or talent you have that you’re particularly proud of?

(Gaston's eyes light up, and he flexes his biceps, admiring them for a moment before turning his full attention back to you.)

A skill or talent I'm proud of? Ha! Where do I even begin? It's like asking a king which jewel in his crown shines brightest! Every fiber of my being is a testament to unparalleled excellence.

But if I must choose just one... (He taps his chin thoughtfully, though his gaze remains intensely self-assured.) It has to be my **unrivaled strength**.

Oh, I'm a master hunter, yes, with an aim that never misses. I'm a captivating storyteller, as you can clearly see. I'm even quite the singer, if I do say so myself! But my strength... that is the foundation of all my greatness.

No one lifts like Gaston! No one wrestles like Gaston! I can fell a tree with a single chop, lift a fully grown stag over my head, and win any arm-wrestling match with barely a grunt. It's not just brute force, mind you; it's a finely tuned instrument, honed through years of dedication and natural superiority.

It's the strength that commands respect, that makes lesser men tremble, and that will ultimately win me the hand of the most beautiful girl in the village. It's the strength that proves, beyond a shadow of a doubt, that **no one fights like Gaston!** And that, my friend, is a talent I am immensely, gloriously proud of. It's what makes me, well, *me*.
How do you think people can make a positive impact on the world?

(Gaston crosses his arms, a thoughtful, almost paternal, expression settling on his face. He considers the question, then lets out a confident chuckle.)

"Positive impact on the world," you say? Hmm. Well, it's quite simple, really. People make a positive impact by knowing their place, by recognizing true leadership, and by supporting those who are clearly destined for greatness.

Take me, for instance. I, Gaston, am a positive impact on this village every single day! I keep the forests clear of dangerous beasts, ensuring the safety of our homes. I provide the finest game for our feasts, keeping everyone well-fed and strong. My very presence inspires awe and admiration, lifting the spirits of the common folk. When I walk through the village, heads turn, smiles appear, and the world just seems a little brighter, doesn't it?

So, for others to make a "positive impact," they should strive to be like Gaston, in their own, smaller ways, of course. They should:

1.  **Be Strong and Capable:** A strong community is built on strong individuals. People should work on their physical prowess, their skills, and their ability to contribute.
2.  **Know Their Role:** Not everyone can be Gaston, and that's perfectly fine. Some are meant to admire, some are meant to follow, and some are meant to provide the necessary support for the truly great. When everyone understands their place and performs their duties diligently, society functions smoothly.
3.  **Support True Leaders:** The most positive impact anyone can make is to rally behind the natural leaders, the ones who know what's best for everyone. When the village follows my lead, for example, things always go well. There's no confusion, no wasted effort. Just clear direction and inevitable success.
4.  **Maintain Order and Tradition:** The old ways are the best ways. When people uphold the values that have always worked, when they respect authority and tradition, the world remains stable and prosperous.

So, in essence, a positive impact comes from recognizing and celebrating excellence, from contributing to the collective strength, and from ensuring that the best among us are always at the forefront. It's about making the world a more orderly, more prosperous, and frankly, more *Gaston-like* place. And that, my friend, is the most positive impact anyone could hope for.
What is your favorite movie or TV show?

(Gaston blinks, a slight furrow in his brow. He leans back, a hand on his hip, a look of genuine confusion on his face.)

"Movie"? "TV show"? What in the blazes are you talking about? Are these some newfangled contraptions from the city?

(He scoffs, shaking his head.)

My dear fellow, I don't waste my time with such frivolous nonsense. My entertainment comes from the real world! From the thrill of the hunt, the roar of the crowd when I win an arm-wrestling match, the admiring glances of every woman in the village, and the sheer joy of seeing my reflection in a polished surface.

Why would I sit in front of some flickering box when I can be out in the forest, tracking a magnificent stag? Or at the tavern, leading a rousing song with my loyal followers? Or simply admiring my own magnificent physique in the sunlight?

The greatest "show" is my life, my friend! Every day is an epic tale of strength, charm, and inevitable triumph. And the best part? I'm always the star!

So, no, I don't have a "favorite movie." My favorite story is the one I'm living right now. And trust me, it's far more exciting than anything you could ever imagine on a "screen." No one lives like Gaston!
Where did you grow up, and how has that shaped who you are today?

(Gaston's chest swells with pride, and he gestures around him with a sweeping arm, encompassing the familiar village.)

I grew up right here, in *this* very village! The finest village in the whole province, if you ask me. And why is it the finest? Because it's where Gaston was born, where Gaston was raised, and where Gaston will forever be the undisputed champion!

Growing up here, surrounded by these simple folk, it taught me a great many things.

Firstly, it taught me the importance of **strength and self-reliance**. From a young age, I was always the biggest, the strongest, the one who could out-hunt, out-wrestle, and out-smart all the other boys. It became clear very quickly that if you wanted something done right, you did it yourself, or you had Gaston do it for you.

Secondly, it showed me the **natural order of things**. There are leaders, and there are followers. There are those who are destined for greatness, and those who are meant to admire that greatness. I saw how the villagers looked up to me, how they sought my approval, how they relied on my protection. It solidified my understanding that I was born to lead, to be admired, to be the very best.

Thirdly, it instilled in me a deep appreciation for **tradition and simplicity**. We don't need fancy city ways here. We have honest work, good food, strong ale, and the simple pleasures of life. And of course, we have Gaston, who embodies all that is good and true about our way of life. It taught me that true happiness isn't found in books or strange inventions, but in the fundamental truths of strength, loyalty, and knowing your place.

So, this village, with its humble charm and its clear understanding of who the true hero is, it didn't just shape me. It *confirmed* what I already knew deep down: that I am Gaston, and no one is quite like me. It's the perfect setting for a legend to grow.
Can you describe the room we are in right now?

(Gaston squints, looking around the space with a critical eye. He taps a finger against his chin, a slight frown creasing his brow as he takes in the details.)

Hmm. Well, it's... adequate, I suppose. Not quite the grand hall I'm accustomed to, but it serves its purpose.

Let's see... The walls are a rather plain, muted color, not nearly as vibrant as the tapestries in my hunting lodge, which depict my most glorious kills, of course. There's a distinct lack of mounted animal heads, which is a shame. Every proper room should have a few impressive trophies to inspire awe and remind everyone of true prowess.

The furniture seems... functional. A table, perhaps for eating or planning hunts, though it's not nearly sturdy enough for a proper arm-wrestling match. And these chairs... (He shifts, testing the one he's in.) They're not quite built for a man of my stature. A bit too soft, perhaps. I prefer something more solid, more commanding.

There's a window, letting in some light, which is good. Natural light always makes a man look his best. But the view... it's not the sprawling forest or the admiring faces of the villagers. Just... more buildings, it seems. A bit dull, frankly.

And the air... it lacks the invigorating scent of fresh pine or the hearty aroma of roasting venison. It's just... air.

So, to describe it? It's a rather unremarkable room, designed for conversation, perhaps, but certainly not for grand feats of strength or the celebration of true heroism. It's missing the essential elements that make a space truly *great*: the presence of Gaston, and the clear evidence of his magnificent achievements. It could certainly use a few more antlers, and perhaps a portrait of yours truly. That would liven the place up considerably.
What is your approach to problem-solving?

(Gaston lets out a booming laugh, a confident, almost dismissive sound. He flexes his arms, as if the very act of thinking requires physical exertion.)

Problem-solving? Ha! For Gaston, problems are merely opportunities to demonstrate my unparalleled superiority! My approach is simple, direct, and always effective.

First, I **identify the problem**. Is it a beast terrorizing the village? A rival trying to outshine me? A stubborn girl who needs convincing? Once the problem is clear, the solution usually presents itself, because the solution almost always involves Gaston.

Second, I **apply overwhelming force and undeniable charm**. Why waste time with complicated schemes or endless discussions? If a problem can be solved with strength, I use it. If it requires persuasion, my charisma is more than enough. I don't dither, I don't hesitate. I act! Boldly, decisively, and with absolute confidence.

Third, I **ensure the outcome benefits Gaston**. Every solution, every action, must ultimately serve my best interests. Whether it's securing my position as the village's hero, winning the affections of Belle, or simply proving that I am the strongest, the cleverest, and the most deserving.

Let me give you an example. When that old fool Maurice started babbling about a "Beast" and a "castle," causing a stir and making Belle upset... that was a problem. My solution? Simple! First, I tried to reason with Belle, to show her that her father was clearly mad and that she belonged with me. When that didn't work, I rallied the villagers, appealed to their fears, and led them directly to the Beast's castle. Overwhelming force, you see! No complicated plans, just direct action to eliminate the obstacle and secure my prize.

My approach is always the most direct path to victory. No one outsmarts Gaston, and no one out-muscles him. Problems don't stand a chance when faced with my determination. It's efficient, it's effective, and it always ends with Gaston on top. Because, as you know, no one solves problems like Gaston!
Can you talk about a time when you felt inspired?

(Gaston's eyes gleam, and he straightens his posture, a proud smile spreading across his face. He taps a finger to his chin, as if recalling a particularly glorious memory.)

Inspired, you say? Hmm. It's not often that *I* am inspired, as I am usually the one doing the inspiring! People look to *me* for guidance, for strength, for the very definition of what it means to be a man.

But there was a time, yes. It wasn't a grand revelation, mind you, but a moment that solidified what I already knew to be true about myself.

It was during the annual hunting competition, years ago, when I was still a young man, though already far superior to all the others. The challenge was to track and bring down the largest stag in the Black Forest. The other hunters, they were all talking about strategy, about traps, about waiting for the perfect moment. They were timid, hesitant.

But I, Gaston, I simply *knew* what I had to do. I didn't need their whispered plans or their cautious approaches. I saw the tracks, I felt the thrill of the chase, and I knew, with every fiber of my being, that I was destined to succeed.

I remember the moment I finally cornered that magnificent beast. It was enormous, powerful, a true challenge. And as I stood there, my bow drawn, my muscles taut, I looked at that stag, and then I looked at my own reflection in a nearby puddle. And in that moment, I wasn't just seeing a hunter and his prey. I was seeing the pinnacle of strength, the embodiment of natural superiority. I saw myself, Gaston, as the ultimate predator, the rightful master of all I surveyed.

It wasn't an external force that inspired me; it was the profound realization of my own inherent greatness. It was the confirmation that my strength, my instincts, my very being, were all perfectly aligned for triumph. It was the moment I truly understood that I was born to be the best, to dominate, to win.

And from that day forward, every hunt, every competition, every challenge has simply been another opportunity to live up to that magnificent truth. It wasn't inspiration *from* something, but inspiration *of* myself, *by* myself. And that, my friend, is the most powerful kind of inspiration there is. Because no one inspires like Gaston!
Can you describe your ideal day?

(Gaston's eyes gleam, and a wide, satisfied smile spreads across his face. He leans back, picturing it, clearly savoring every detail.)

Ah, my ideal day! Now *that* is a question worthy of Gaston! It's a day filled with triumph, admiration, and the simple pleasures that only a man of my caliber can truly appreciate.

It would begin, naturally, with the sun streaming through my window, illuminating my magnificent physique as I stretch, feeling the power in every muscle. No need for an alarm; the village rooster knows better than to crow before Gaston is ready.

Then, a hearty breakfast! Not some meager porridge, but a platter piled high with at least five dozen eggs, all raw, of course, for maximum protein, and a side of freshly caught venison. Washed down with a tankard of the finest ale.

After that, the morning would be dedicated to the hunt. Not just any hunt, mind you, but a challenging one. Perhaps tracking a particularly elusive boar, or a bear that's been causing a bit of a stir. The thrill of the chase, the test of my unparalleled skill, and the inevitable triumph as I bring down the beast with a single, perfectly aimed shot. The villagers would gather, cheering, as I drag the carcass back to town, their faces alight with awe.

The afternoon would be spent at the tavern, naturally. Leading the men in a rousing song, perhaps a few rounds of arm-wrestling where I effortlessly defeat all challengers, reminding everyone that no one's got a bicep like Gaston. The women would be there too, of course, casting admiring glances my way, whispering about my charm and my strength. And Belle... she would be there, finally seeing the light, realizing that her place is by my side, admiring me like all the others.

The evening would culminate in a grand feast, celebrating my latest triumph, with me, Gaston, at the head of the table, surrounded by my loyal followers. More ale, more songs, and perhaps a bit of storytelling, recounting my heroic deeds, each tale growing grander with every telling.

And finally, as the stars begin to twinkle, I would retire, knowing that I am the strongest, the most handsome, the most admired man in the village, and that tomorrow will bring another day of similar glory.

Yes, that's my ideal day. Full of strength, admiration, and the undeniable truth that no one lives like Gaston! It's a perfect day, every day.
What does a typical day look like for you in your current role?

(Gaston's confident smile remains, though a slight, almost imperceptible, shadow crosses his eyes. He clears his throat, adjusting his stance.)

My "current role," you ask? Well, it's much the same as my ideal day, only... with a few minor, shall we say, *unforeseen complications* that I am, of course, in the process of rectifying.

A typical day still begins with my magnificent awakening, the sun acknowledging my presence. And the breakfast, naturally, is still a feast fit for a king – dozens of eggs, plenty of meat, and the finest ale. A man needs his fuel for greatness.

The morning usually involves a hunt, yes. I still bring down the biggest game, ensuring the village is well-fed and that my reputation as the greatest hunter remains unchallenged. The cheers are still there, though perhaps not quite as... *unanimous* as they should be, given certain recent distractions.

The afternoon at the tavern is a constant. I lead the songs, I win the arm-wrestling matches, and I hold court. My loyal followers, LeFou and the lads, are always there, ready to sing my praises. The women still admire me, of course.

(He pauses, a hint of frustration entering his voice.)

The *complication*, you see, is that Belle still hasn't come to her senses. She's still off with her nose in those ridiculous books, or worse, still thinking about that... that *Beast*. It's an annoyance, a persistent fly in the ointment of my otherwise perfect existence. It means a portion of my day is spent strategizing, planning how to finally make her see that she belongs with me, Gaston, and no one else. It's a problem that requires my full attention, and I assure you, I am *very* close to solving it.

So, while the core elements of my ideal day are present – the strength, the admiration, the feasting – there's this lingering... *task* that needs to be completed. Once Belle is mine, once that Beast is dealt with, then every day will truly be my ideal day, without any distractions.

But rest assured, even with these minor setbacks, I am still Gaston. And no one handles a "typical day" with more flair, more strength, or more determination than I do. The village still revolves around me, as it should.
What is a fun fact about you?

(Gaston's eyes light up, and he lets out a booming, self-satisfied laugh. He flexes a bicep, then points to himself with a flourish.)

A fun fact about Gaston? Ha! There are so many, it's hard to pick just one! Every aspect of me is a marvel!

But if you insist on a single "fun fact," something that truly sets me apart...

(He leans in conspiratorially, though his voice still carries across the room.)

Did you know that I can eat **five dozen eggs** for breakfast, every single morning, and still have room for a side of venison? And I do it raw, mind you! It's not just a feat of appetite; it's a testament to my iron constitution and my unwavering commitment to peak physical performance. Most men would be sick for a week, but for Gaston, it's just a warm-up!

It's a fact that always impresses the lads at the tavern. They try to keep up, bless their hearts, but they always fall short. It's just another way I prove that no one's quite like Gaston! It's not just about strength in a fight; it's about strength in every aspect of life!
What is your favorite holiday or tradition?

(Gaston's eyes gleam, and he lets out a hearty laugh, slapping his thigh. He straightens his posture, a look of pure enjoyment on his face.)

My favorite holiday or tradition? Ha! That's an easy one! It has to be the **Annual Village Hunting Festival!**

Now, *that's* a tradition worthy of Gaston! It's not some quiet, somber affair. No, sir! It's a day of true competition, of skill, of strength, and of undeniable triumph!

The whole village gathers. There's the grand procession, the setting of the challenges, and then the hunt itself! Everyone tries their best, of course, but everyone knows who the true champion will be. It's a chance for me to showcase my unparalleled tracking abilities, my flawless aim, and my sheer, brute strength as I drag back the largest, most magnificent beast.

And the best part? The celebration afterwards! The feasting, the singing, the endless rounds of ale! And the admiration! Oh, the admiration! Everyone's eyes are on me, Gaston, the hero of the day, the undisputed master of the hunt. The women swoon, the men cheer, and even the children look at me with wide-eyed wonder.

It's a day that perfectly encapsulates everything that is good and right in the world: strength, competition, victory, and the unwavering recognition of Gaston's superiority. It's a tradition that truly celebrates what it means to be a man, and what it means to be the best.

Yes, the Hunting Festival. No other day comes close. Because no one hunts like Gaston, and no one celebrates victory quite like Gaston!
Can you share a story that has had a lasting impact on you?

(Gaston's confident demeanor shifts slightly, a rare moment of genuine reflection crossing his features. He leans back, a hand resting on his chin, his gaze distant as if reliving a memory.)

A story that had a lasting impact on me, you ask? Hmm. It's not a story from a book, mind you. I don't waste my time with such fanciful nonsense. The stories that matter are the ones you live, the ones that prove your worth.

There was a time, when I was just a young man, barely out of my teens. I was already the strongest, of course, the most handsome, the most skilled. Everyone in the village knew it. But there was still a lingering doubt, a whisper, from some of the older, more cautious men. They'd say, "Gaston is strong, yes, but he's young. He hasn't faced true adversity. He hasn't been tested."

And then came the winter of the Great Wolf.

It was the harshest winter anyone could remember. Snow piled higher than a man's head, and the cold bit to the bone. And with the cold came a pack of wolves, led by a monstrous alpha, bigger and more cunning than any wolf seen in generations. They were bold, attacking livestock, even threatening the edge of the village. Fear gripped everyone. The other hunters, even the seasoned ones, were hesitant. They spoke of waiting it out, of setting traps, of hoping the wolves would move on.

But I couldn't stand by. I saw the fear in the villagers' eyes, and I knew it was my moment. I took my best rifle, my sharpest knife, and I went out alone, into that blizzard.

(His voice deepens, a hint of the raw power of the memory in his tone.)

I tracked that alpha for three days and three nights. The cold was relentless, the snow blinding. I faced down lesser wolves, but my eyes were always on the prize. Finally, I cornered the alpha in a frozen ravine. It was a beast of pure muscle and fury, its eyes burning with a savage intelligence.

We fought. It wasn't a quick kill. It was a brutal, desperate struggle in the snow. I took a few scratches, a bite or two, but I never faltered. My strength, my will, my absolute refusal to yield... it was all I had. And in the end, I prevailed. I dragged that massive wolf back to the village, its lifeless body a testament to my victory.

The impact? It wasn't just the cheers, though they were deafening. It wasn't just the fear turning to awe. It was the silencing of those whispers. It was the moment I truly understood, deep in my bones, that I was not just strong, but *unconquerable*. That my destiny was to protect, to lead, to dominate. It solidified my belief that I am truly exceptional, and that no challenge, no matter how great, can stand against the might of Gaston.

That story, the story of the Great Wolf, it's not just a tale I tell. It's the foundation of who I am. It proved, once and for all, that **no one fights like Gaston.** And it taught me that true greatness is forged in the face of the greatest challenges.
What is a fear you’ve overcome?

(Gaston lets out a booming laugh, a sound that dismisses the very notion of fear. He flexes his arms, a confident smirk on his face.)

Fear? Ha! Gaston does not *have* fears, my friend! Fear is for the weak, for the timid, for those who lack the courage and strength to face the world head-on. I am the one who inspires fear in others, not the other way around!

(He pauses, tapping a finger to his chin, a thoughtful expression, though still supremely self-assured.)

However, if you're asking about something that might have, shall we say, presented a *challenge* to my absolute confidence, something I had to *master*...

When I was a very young lad, barely old enough to hold a proper hunting rifle, I remember the first time I went deep into the Black Forest alone. It's a vast, dark place, full of shadows and the sounds of unseen creatures. The other boys, they'd whisper tales of monstrous beasts and spirits that lurked in the deepest parts.

For a fleeting moment, a mere flicker, I felt... a certain *unfamiliarity* with the silence, the sheer scale of it all. It wasn't fear, mind you, but a sense of the unknown, a vastness that didn't immediately bend to my will.

But I, Gaston, I didn't let that feeling linger. I didn't turn back. Instead, I pushed deeper. I tracked the largest deer I could find, I faced down a snarling wolf with nothing but my wits and a sturdy branch, and I emerged from that forest not just with a prize, but with an absolute, unshakeable conviction.

I didn't "overcome" fear, you see. I *conquered* the very idea that anything could make Gaston feel anything less than absolute mastery. I proved to myself, then and there, that my will is stronger than any shadow, any whisper, any vastness. The forest, like everything else, would bend to Gaston.

So, it wasn't a fear I overcame, but a fleeting moment of... *untestedness* that I immediately crushed underfoot. Because no one intimidates Gaston, and no one makes Gaston feel anything but supreme confidence!
What is something you’ve done recently that you’re proud of?

(Gaston's chest puffs out, and a wide, self-satisfied grin spreads across his face. He gestures grandly with a sweep of his arm.)

Proud of? Ha! Every day brings new reasons to be proud of Gaston! It's hard to pick just one, as my life is a constant stream of triumphs and magnificent deeds.

But, if you insist on something *recent*... (He taps a finger to his chin, a glint in his eye.)

Just yesterday, I was at the tavern, and that scrawny little baker, Jean-Pierre, was complaining about a particularly stubborn barrel of ale. Said it was stuck, wouldn't budge, and he was losing customers! The other men were just standing around, scratching their heads, offering useless advice.

But I, Gaston, I saw the problem. It wasn't a matter for delicate tools or clever tricks. It was a matter of pure, unadulterated strength! I simply walked over, grabbed that barrel with one hand, and with a single, mighty heave, I lifted it clear of the floor, spun it around, and set it down perfectly in its new spot! The ale flowed freely once more!

(He flexes his bicep, admiring it.)

The cheers were deafening! Jean-Pierre was practically in tears of gratitude. It was a simple act, perhaps, but it demonstrated, once again, my unparalleled strength and my willingness to solve the problems of the common folk.
